org.jsonurl

Class NumberBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jsonurl.NumberBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    NumberText

    public class NumberBuilder
extends Object
implements NumberText
    A NumberBuilder implements the builder pattern for JSON→URL number literals. An instance of this class may be used to parse JSON→URL number literals from text as Java SE values.

    Single Use

    NumberBuilder may be single use, where the literal text is provided via a constructor followed by a call to a method to test and/or build a value. For example: 

     // Example 1
 Number n = new NumberBuilder("1.234").build();
 
 // Example 2
 NumberBuilder nb = new NumberBuilder("1.234");
 if (!nb.isNumber()) {
     // handle error
 }
 double d = nb.toDouble();

    Reuse

    An instance of NumberBuilder may also be reused via a call to the reset() method. 

     NumberBuilder nb = new NumberBuilder();
 if (!nb.parse("1.234")) {
     // handle the error
 }

 // equal to new Double("1.234")
 Number n = nb.build();
 
 .
 .
 .
 
 if (!nb.reset().parse("98765432100")) {
     // handle the error
 }

 // equal to new Long("98765432100")
 n = nb.build();

    Static Methods

    NumberBuilder also provides static methods to test literals without allocating an instance. They're useful if you want test validity but don't need access to the parsed value. 

     boolean b = NumberBuilder.isNumber("1234");
 boolean b = NumberBuilder.isNumber("abcd");
 boolean b = NumberBuilder.isInteger("1234.5");
    Since:
    2019-09-01
    Author:
    jsonurl.org, David MacCormack

    • Constructor Detail

      • NumberBuilder

        public NumberBuilder()
        Create a new NumberBuilder.

        This NumberBuilder will not have any text. You'll need to call parse(CharSequence, int, int).

      • NumberBuilder

                     int start,

        start - start index
        stop - stop index

      • NumberBuilder

        public NumberBuilder(CharSequence text)
        Create a new NumberBuilder with the given text.

        This is a convenience for NumberBuilder(s, 0, s.length()).

    • Method Detail

      • reset

        public NumberBuilder reset()
        Reset the instance for reuse. You may reliably call parse(CharSequence, int, int) again after calling this method.

      • getExponentType

      • parse

        public boolean parse(CharSequence text,
                     int start,
                     int stop)
        Parse the given character sequence.

        Any BigMathProvider given in the constructor is not used in this method, so it is safe to assume you can parse text without regard to how a number might be built later via the build(boolean) method.

        Parameters:
        text - a valid CharSequence
        start - an index
        stop - an index
        Returns:
        true if the CharSequence was successfully parsed

        Determine if the given CharSequence is a valid JSON→URL number literal.

        Convenience for isNumber(s, 0, s.length(), false).

      • build

        public static final Number build(NumberText num,
                                 boolean primitiveOnly)
        Build a Number from the given NumberText. Convenience for build(t, primitiveOnly, null).
        Parameters:
        num - a valid NumberText
        primitiveOnly - return a Long or Double

      • build

        public static final Number build(NumberText num,
                                 boolean primitiveOnly,
                                 BigMathProvider mcp)
        Build a Number from the given NumberText.

        The benefit of this method (over toDouble(NumberText) or toBigDecimal(NumberText, BigMathProvider)) is that it has the logic to return a Number tailored to the value itself. For example, if the value can be represented as a Long then it will be.

        Parameters:
        num - a valid NumberText
        primitiveOnly - return a Long or Double
        mcp - a valid BigMathProvider or null
        Returns:
        an instance of java.lang.Number

      • isLong

        public static final boolean isLong(NumberText num)
        Test if the given NumberText can be stored in a long.
        Parameters:
        num - a valid NumberText

      • toLong

        public static final long toLong(NumberText num)
        Convert the given NumberText to a long value.

        You must call isLong(NumberText) first to determine if the number is a valid long value. Otherwise, you may trigger an exception or get a nonsense result.

        Parameters:
        num - a valid NumberText
